metadata.title: Getting Started with Databricks — Analyzing COVID-19 | by Renan Ferreira | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Getting Started with Databricks — Analyzing COVID-19
metadata.description: Note from Towards Data Science’s editors: While we allow independent authors to publish articles in accordance with our rules and guidelines, we do not endorse each author’s contribution. You should…

all_paragraphs: Note from Towards Data Science’s editors: While we allow independent authors to publish articles in accordance with our rules and guidelines, we do not endorse each author’s contribution. You should not rely on an author’s works without seeking professional advice. See our Reader Terms for details.
A typical Data Science workflow is composed of the following steps:
Each of these steps requires a set of expertise that can be divided in:
Data engineers: develop, construct, test, and maintain data pipelines
Data scientists: use a variety of methods to extract insights (machine learning models)
Data analysts: take data prepared by data engineers to extract insights from it in the form of graphs, charts, and dashboards (Business Intelligence)
Platform administrators: responsible for managing and supporting data infrastructure (DevOps)

Databricks is a unified platform that provides the tools necessary for each of these jobs. In this article, we will analyze the COVID-19 data of Brazil by creating a data pipeline and indicating the responsibilities of each team member.

To complete the next steps, you will need to have access to a Databricks account. The simplest way of starting one is by creating a Databricks Community account at https://community.cloud.databricks.com

The first step is to configure a cluster. Databricks is a Spark-based platform, which is one of the most popular Big Data analytics framework. Spark is, by nature, a distributed system, and that’s why the cluster creation process involves the selection of virtual machines for the driver and the worker nodes. Basically, the driver is the orchestrator of the cluster, and the worker nodes are responsible for the heavy work.

The platform administrator is responsible for selecting the appropriate family of virtual machines based on the use case, the spark version, number of worker nodes, and autoscaling configurations. ETL processes may need memory-optimized devices, and heavy Machine Learning training processes may run on GPUs, for example.

Go to the Clusters page and create a new cluster using the 6.6 ML runtime. If you are using Azure Databricks or AWS, you will need to select the VM family of the driver and the worker nodes. For this tutorial, you can choose the cheapest ones.

Data ingestion can be a challenging area. Usually, companies have data stored in multiple databases, and nowadays is really common the use of streams of data. Fortunately, Databricks, in conjunction to Spark and Delta Lake, can help us with a simple interface for batch or streaming ETL (extract, transform and load).
In this tutorial, we will start with the most straightforward type of ETL, loading data from a CSV file.
First, we need to download our Dataset. Visit the following URL:
Decompress the file, access the Data menu, and click on the Add Data button. Next, upload the CSV file downloaded previously.

After the upload is completed, we will create a new table with the information presented in the dataset. Click the Create Table UI, rename the table to covid, set the first row as the header, and finally, click on the create button.
With the table created, we can start to analyze our dataset. First, we need to create a new python Notebook. Go to the
Worspace > Users > YOUR EMAIL
Click on the arrow and create a new Notebook

Although been a python notebook, Databricks supports multiple languages inside your notebook. In our case, we will mostly use SparkSQL. If you are familiar with SQL, SparkSQL will feel like home to you.
Let’s start by viewing our new table:
You should see a table like this:

As a Data Analyst, you should be able to extract valuable information about the data. First, we need to understand the meaning of each column of the table. One way of doing this is by using the DESCRIBE function:

Analyzing the two tables, we can infer that, when the column place_type is equal to state each row represents the total number for that state. Let's try to plot the evolution of the number of deaths for the three most populated states:
Click on the Bar Chart button, Plot Optionsand configure a Line chart with the following configurations:
Now we have a great representation of the evolution of the number of deaths during the pandemic time. We could, for example, embed this graph in a Dashboard to alert the population of those states.
Next, we will try to predict future values of the time series plotted previously. To do that, we will use a Facebook library called Prophet
First, we need to install some dependencies. Go to
and install the following dependencies using PyPI
We will try to predict the number of deaths in the future for Minas Gerais (MG). So the first step is to collect our data.
*Maybe you will need to clear the state of you notebook
Next, we will use Prophet to fit a model and finally plot "the future"
You should see the following chart with the predictions:

Our goal was to demonstrate all the steps of a Data Science workflow. That’s why we didn’t describe how the time-series model works. If you follow this tutorial, you should have a great view of the Databricks platform.
The full notebook is available at this public repository
If you have any doubt, you can find me at:
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
